tit.cmt: 後列で「神封」の読みは「じんぷ」となっていますので、一応そのように訳出しましたが、広辞苑では「しんぽう」となっており、用語集では漢字表記のまま「定訳不明」とされています。

sen.j: 神封（じんぷ）とは、神社に対して寄進された封戸。
sen.e: Jinpu is fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrine and temple) donated to a shrine.
sen.cmt: 用語集で「封戸」は"fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrines and temples)"となっていますが、"courtier"が単数なので"shrines and temples"→"shrine and temple"としました。
sen.e: Jinpu is fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrine and temple) donated to a shrine.
Jinpu is fuko (a vassal household allotted to courtier, shrine and temple) donated to a shrine.

sen.j: 神封の住民は租税や課役を神社に納めたり、祝 (神職)などの役職を務めることで神社に奉仕した。
sen.e: The residents of jinpu served the shrine by paying tax, performing allocated jobs, serving as Hafuri (an ancient Shinto priest) or other posts, and so on.
sen.cmt: 用語集で「租税」は"land tax"となっていますが、これは「地租」のみを指していると思いますので、ここでは"tax"としました。原文には (神職) とありますが、リンク先の単語が抽出されるバグのようですので、訳出しておりません。
sen.e: The residents of jinpu served the shrine by paying tax, performing allocated jobs, serving as Hafuri (an ancient Shinto priest) or other posts, and so on.

sen.j: こうした住民を神封戸（じんふこ）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: These residents are called "Jinfuko."
These residents are called "Jinfuko."
These residents are called "Jinfuko."

sen.j: 一般的には神戸（じんこ、かんべ）または神部（かんべ、かむべ）と同義とされるが、その成立時期や初期における役割には差異があったと考えられ、両者の混合が進んだのは、奈良時代後期から平安時代初期にかけてと考えられている。
sen.e: Although it is generally deemed to be synonymous with 神戸 (pronounced "jinko" or "kanbe") or 神部 (pronounced "kanbe" or "kambe"), it is considered that their period of origin and original role were different with each other; it is considered that the two became increasingly confused from the late Nara period to the early Heian period.
sen.cmt: 原文の「両者」は、「神封戸と神戸」もしくは「神封戸と神部」のことと解釈しました。「神戸」「神部」はともに「かんべ」の読みを持つため、別の語であると分かるよう漢字表記にしました。
sen.e: Although it is generally deemed to be synonymous with "jinko" (also known as "kanbe," written as 神戸 or 神部 in Chinese characters), it is considered that their period of origin and original role were different with each other; it is considered that the two became increasingly confused from the late Nara period to the early Heian period.
sen.cmt: "jinko" (also known as "kanbe," written as 神戸 or 神部 in Chinese characters)としました。
sen.e: Although it is generally deemed to be synonymous with "jinko" (also known as "kanbe," written as 神戸 or 神部 in Chinese characters), it is considered that their period of origin and original role were different with each other; it is considered that the two became increasingly confused from the late Nara period to the early Heian period.

sen.j: 神戸の多くが大化前代に遡ることが出来ると考えられる所謂部民であったと考えられるのに対して、神封は律令制による食封制度の一環として成立したと考えられている。
sen.e: While it is considered that many of jinko were Bemin (people who belonged to Yamato dynasty) which date back to the period before the Taika Reforms, jinpu is considered to have originated as part of Jikifu system (a kind of stipend: fuko are given as an income source) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

sen.j: ただし、養老令などに直接規定したものは無く、『令集解』の禄令令条外条における朱説（明法家による注釈とされる注記）に示されているに過ぎない。
sen.e: However, there are no definite rules about it in Yoro-ryo (Yoro Code) and so on; it is only mentioned in 朱説 (notes which is said to be written by a lawyer) in 禄令令条外条 of "Ryonoshuge" (Commentaries on the Civil Statutes).

sen.j: 従って神封に関する規定は太政官符・太政官牒で定められていた。
sen.e: Therefore, provisions for jinpu was made in Daijokanpu (official documents from Daijokan (Grand Council of State) to local governments) and Daijokancho (official documents from Daijokan to Buddhist temples).

sen.j: 当初は神封戸は神戸とは違い、賦役令の封戸に関する規定によって庸調及び課役のみを負担して田租の半分は神社に残りは国家に納めていたと考えられている。
sen.e: Originally, unlike jinko, only Yo (tax in kind), Cho (tributes), and allocated job were imposed on jinfuko, under the provision for fuko in Fuyaku ryo (tax law); they paid half of denso (rice field tax) to the shrine, and another half to the state.
sen.cmt: 用語集で「賦役令」は"Fuyaku ryo (tax structure)"となっていますが、これは「令」は法のことと思われますので "tax law"としました。

sen.j: ところが、天平11年（739年）に封戸の租は全て封主（神封の場合は神社）に納めることとされ、神戸との税制的な違いが消滅した。
sen.e: However, the difference from jinko in the tax system disappeared when it was decided in 739 that fuko should pay all the rice tax to 封主 (in case of jinpu, 封主 is the shrine).
sen.cmt: 「封主」読み方、定訳ともに不明
sen.e: However, the difference from jinko in the tax system disappeared when it was decided in 739 that fuko should pay all the rice tax to fushu (in case of jinpu, fushu is the shrine).

sen.j: また、この頃より神社に対しても官人と同様に位階を授けて位封を支給する制度が行われるようになり、官人の位階と同様の位封が授けられた（ただし、『続日本紀』などの記録によれば、全額が支給されていない例もあったことが判明する）。
sen.e: About that time, a new system was introduced: shrines were conferred Ikai (Court rank) and Ifu (fuko which were given according to ikai) like government officials (especially one of low to medium rank); the number of ifu for a shrine was the same as that for a government official of the same ikai (however, according to the records in "Shoku Nihongi" (Continuation of Chronicles of Japan) and so on, there were cases in which ifu were not paid in full).
sen.cmt: 用語集で「位封」は "ifu (families provided to the third rank and higher" と中途半端で終わっているため、これは使用しませんでした。原文にある「官人の位階と同様の位封」の、『同様』の指すところが定かではありませんが、「同じ位階にあたる官人と同じ戸数の位封」と解釈して訳出しました。位封を数える単位は「戸」となるはずですが、原文には「全額」とあり、金銭での支給のように受け取れますので、一応 "paid in full" としておきました。

sen.j: 平安時代初期になると、実質的な差異が失われた神戸と神封が混同されて同一に扱われるようになった。
sen.e: In the early Heian period, jinko and jinpu, making no actual difference with each other, began to be confused and treated as the same.
